ygData.msgSnippet: I just tried setting up a crawl using SURT prefix scope (1.6.0). It s seeded with only 20 URLs: http://age1116.com/ http://barca.daa.jp/ http://blog.goo.ne.jp/

I just tried setting up a crawl using SURT prefix scope (1.6.0). It's
seeded with only 20 URLs:

http://age1116.com/
http://barca.daa.jp/
http://blog.goo.ne.jp/
http://blog.livedoor.com/
http://blog.seesaa.jp/
http://d.hatena.ne.jp/
http://fc2.com/
http://japan.cnet.com/
http://jugem.jp/
http://slashdot.jp/
http://www.atmarkit.co.jp/fwcr/special/ajax_kaitai01/01.html
http://www.blogpeople.net/
http://www.cheaper.jp/
http://www.cocolog-nifty.com/
http://www.excite.co.jp/blog/
http://www.geocities.co.jp/SiliconValley-Cupertino/8480/
http://www.hokkaido-np.co.jp/
http://www.infoseek.co.jp/
http://www.musubiha.com/
http://www.yaplog.jp/

With an even smaller manually constructed SURT file:

http://(com,age1116,
http://(com,cnet,japan,
http://(com,cocolog-nifty,
http://(com,fc2,
http://(com,livedoor,
http://(com,masubiha,
http://(jp,
http://(net,blogpeople,

From the documentation these should work.

The seeds *were* *not* used to generate SURT prefixes.

The SURT dump given this configuration was:

http://(http,)//

and the crawl grabbed only about 100 documents: it became obvious that
my intent (i.e., grab anything in .jp or fc2.com or...) was not happening.

Can someone suss out where I screwed these up?

Thanks.

    -tree
